quoteFirst: By the time I reached the second floor the building had ceased shaking, and I went back, got my clothes, and went into the street. In the building across the street twelve persons were killed.
quoteLast: we were in the public square, with about 1,500 other refugees, when a severe shock was felt. People became panic stricken; some prayed, women fainted, and children shrieked and cried.
title: Complete Story of the San Francisco Horror
author: Linthicum, Richard, 1859-1934; Fallows, Samuel, 1835-1922; White, Trumbull, 1868-1941

quoteFirst: The variations in the wet bulb are due to the currents of air, which beginning
quoteLast: , pass into a rather constant strongish west wind about 11.5 or 2 P.M., and even almost become hot.  The climate is excessively dry, as indicated by the effects it has on furniture, etc.
title: Journals of Travels in Assam, Burma, Bhootan, Afghanistan and the Neighbouring Countries
author: Griffith, William, 1810-1845

quoteFirst: A cutting north-easter was blowing, accompanied with snow and sleet. We forded,
quoteLast: , the Kokajeri river, a mountain stream about thirty yards wide, unfordable except upon the sea-beach. At midday we halted at Tchergári, a fishing-village on the shores of the Caspian.
title: A Ride to India across Persia and Baluchistán
author: De Windt, Harry, 1856-1933

quoteFirst: The flock has suffered the loss of two female birds (they were probably caught by a cat); otherwise the company has remained intact for six weeks. As in the case of the original flock, these birds fed early in the morning, again at
quoteLast: , and were rarely seen in the afternoon. On one occasion, they left the feeding-ground by mounting high in the air and taking a long, direct flight to the westward. Besides the box elder and crab-apple seeds, the birds have eaten wild-cherry pits, poison-ivy berries, and gray-birch seeds.
title: Bird-Lore, March-April 1916
author: Various; Chapman, Frank M. (Frank Michler), 1864-1945 [Editor]

quoteFirst: Amidst such exciting and busy scenes, the time flew rapidly away until the 17th of January, when
quoteLast: the report of a carronade came echoing up the valley. This was the preconcerted signal which was to announce to us that the vessel was safely at anchor in Hanover Bay.
title: Journals of Two Expeditions of Discovery in North-West and Western Australia, Volume 1
author: Grey, George, 1812-1898

quoteFirst: He was ordered to repair an old broken bridge about two miles up the Chickamauga, and to follow General Davis at 4 a.m., and the Fifteenth Army Corps was ordered to follow at daylight.  But General Howard found that to repair the bridge was more of a task than was at first supposed, and we were all compelled to cross the Chickamauga on the new pontoon-bridge at its mouth.  By
quoteLast: General Jeff. C.
title: Memoirs of the Union's Three Great Civil War Generals
author: Grant, Ulysses S. (Ulysses Simpson), 1822-1885; Sheridan, Philip Henry, 1831-1888; Sherman, William T. (William Tecumseh), 1820-1891; Widger, David, 1932-2021? [Editor]

quoteFirst: Pittsburg through Monterey, which it reached
quoteLast: on the 4th, and bivouacked that night near Mickey's in the rear of Hardee's corps. The First Corps, under General Polk, consisted of two divisions, under Cheatham and Clark.
title: The Rise and Fall of the Confederate Government, Volume 2
author: Davis, Jefferson, 1808-1889

quoteFirst: [63] Our regiment and the 2d New Jersey regiment was ordered to cross the River at our encampment and proceed up the River on the opposite side, to take possession of the ground at Tyuga to cover the fording place for the army and horses to cross the River, arrived at Tyuga
quoteLast: .[64] At night Gen. Sullivan sent off a small scout[65] to discover Shemung[66] (of one Captain and seven men,) which lay about twelve miles up the Tiyuga branch.
title:
The Journal of Lieut. John L. Hardenbergh of the Second New York Continental Regiment from May 1 to October 3, 1779, in General Sullivan's Campaign Against the Western Indians
With an Introduction, Copious Historical Notes, and Maps of the Battle-field of Newtown and Groveland Ambuscade
author: Hardenbergh, John Leonard, 1748-1806; Beatty, Erkuries, 1759-1823 [Contributor]; Dearborn, Henry, 1751-1829 [Contributor]; Grant, Thomas, active 1779 [Contributor]; Hawley, Charles, 1819-1885 [Contributor]; Clark, John S., 1823-1912 [Editor]

quoteFirst: The consuls of the year were Gabinus and Piso. The first was notoriously hostile, of the second Cicero hoped to make a friend, the more so as he was a kinsman of his daughter's husband. He gives a lively picture of an interview with him. "It was
quoteTime: nearly eleven o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: when we went to him. He came out of a dirty hovel to meet us, with his slippers on, and his head muffled up.
title: Roman life in the days of Cicero
author: Church, Alfred John, 1829-1912

quoteFirst: The statement that a mountain is 15,000 feet high is, by itself, little more impressive, than that it is 3,000; we want something more before we can mentally compare Mont Blanc and Snowdon. Indeed, the same people who guess of a mountain's height at a number of feet much exceeding the reality, show, when they are cross-examined, that they fail to appreciate in any tolerable degree the real meaning of the figures. An old lady one day,
quoteLast: , proposed to walk from the Aeggischhorn to the Jungfrau-Joch, and to return for luncheon--the distance being a good twelve hours' journey for trained mountaineers. Every detail of which the huge mass is composed is certain to be underestimated.
title:
English Prose
A Series of Related Essays for the Discussion and Practice of the Art of Writing
author: Roe, Frederick William, 1874- [Editor]; Elliott, George Roy, 1883-1963 [Editor]

quoteFirst: We left this place
quoteLast: , and were again conveyed, with more sunshine than wind, aboard our ship.
title: The Journal of a Voyage to Lisbon
author: Fielding, Henry, 1707-1754

quoteFirst: "That there cable was received in London at six-thirty this evening, and the _Evening Gazette_ Meguet quoted from was the latest issue--
quoteLast: I shall go down early to the office to-night!"
title: The Man of Iron
author: Dehan, Richard, 1863-1932

quoteFirst: When I heard a knock at my door
quoteTime: about eleven o’clock in the morning
quoteLast: and the voice of Mere Bernier told me that Rouletabille wanted me to get up, I threw my window wide open and looked out in delight. The bay was of an incomparable beauty, and the sea was so transparent that the rays of the sun pierced through it as they would have done through a mirror without quicksilver, so that one could perceive the rocks, the anemones and the moss in the sea bottom just as if the waters had ceased to cover them and left them bared to the eye.
title: The perfume of the lady in black
author: Leroux, Gaston, 1868-1927; Simont [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: They begin before dawn and halt at
quoteLast: , the time of the morning meal. When a second march is made they load at 3 P.M. and advance till dark; thus fifteen miles would be the average of fast travelling. In places of danger they will cover twenty-six or twenty-seven miles of ground without halting to eat or rest: nothing less, however, than regard for "dear life" can engender such activity.
title: First Footsteps in East Africa
author: Burton, Richard Francis, Sir, 1821-1890

quoteFirst: However, before long our gallant Chief found he had got Marmont into a trap at last, and immediately knew how to take advantage of it. A brisk cannonade commenced on both sides, and
quoteLast: the columns on our right moved to the attack.
title:
A British Rifle Man
The Journals and Correspondence of Major George Simmons, Rifle Brigade, During the Peninsular War and the Campaign of Waterloo
author: Simmons, George, 1785-1858; Verner, William Willoughby Cole, 1852-1922 [Editor]

quoteFirst: But that day,
quoteTime: about eleven o’clock in the morning
quoteLast: , Nicholl having accidentally let a glass slip from his hand, the glass, instead of falling, remained suspended in the air.
title: From the Earth to the Moon; and, Round the Moon
author: Verne, Jules, 1828-1905

quoteFirst: It was
quoteTime: about eleven o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: ; the sun illumined the hut; the birds were singing merrily in the forest. Father Sanchez had taken up the hand mill, and was grinding the wheat, while his wife, after sifting the wheat, pounded it, and formed it into light cakes, called tortillas, which, after being griddled, would form the solid portion of the breakfast.
title: Stronghand; or, The Noble Revenge
author: Aimard, Gustave, 1818-1883; Wraxall, Lascelles, Sir, 1828-1865 [Translator]

quoteFirst: SINKING SENSATIONS:--Many women have a feeling of weakness or "goneness" at
quoteTime: about eleven o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: , and are led by it to the injurious practice of eating between meals. It is often due to indigestion, or to the use of beer or wine.
title:
Alcohol: A Dangerous and Unnecessary Medicine, How and Why
What Medical Writers Say
author: Allen, Martha Meir, 1854-1926

quoteFirst: The meeting terminated at
quoteLast: , and immediately afterwards the central committee sat upstairs in a room at an angle of the building, when I was appointed chairman. We first took up the question of funds, and I suggested that each member of the Assembly should subscribe one rupee.

Gold, Sport, and Coffee Planting in Mysore
